text: We will hear arguments first this morning in Anderson Bros. v. Valencia.
Thank you, Your Honor.
Will these issues all disappear under the new statute that was passed last year?
They will, Your Honor, but not with respect to contracts that were written with respect to the former statute, the present statute, which are now--
Cases like yours?
--That's right, Your Honor.
And what is the volume of those contracts, have you any idea?
Well there are... this contract that is before the Court is the paradigm of the industries contract.
Mr. Chief Justice--
Mr. Alop, forgive me, before you start, but where is it... that the requirement that it appear on the face... where is that in the statute?
--That's in Regulation Z, Your Honor, at 12 C.F.R. Section 226.8(a).
Now heres's Regulation Z at page 2 of the petition... what's the language in Regulation Z that says the front?

The language in 226.8(a)(1) is that all of the disclosures shall be made together on either the note or other instrument evidencing the obligation on the same side of the page and above or adjacent to the place for the customer's signature.
What are you reading from?
--I'm not reading from the brief, Your Honor.
Where do we find it?
Twelve, Code of Federal Regulations--
Isn't that the crux of this case?
--The other side has not disputed this.
Yes, but it wouldn't... it would only be because of the regulation?
That's correct, Your Honor.
If there weren't any provision like that, no Court has construed the statute to require that.
--That's correct.

Well now, the Proposed Official Staff Interpretation 173, which as I understand it has not yet become effective, does say that this kind of interest need not be... need not appear on the face of the statement.
I would not dispute that, Your Honor.
Where does the relevant text to that regulation appear?
Yes.
I believe it's in the... page 33 of the addendum... no, 54 of the addendum.
One minute left, Your Honor?
One.
Thank you.
Thank you, gentlemen.
